Award.AwardTitle: NSF PI Meeting - Smart and Connected Communities (S&CC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Smart and Connected Communities (S&CC) vision is to improve the well-being and prosperity of diverse communities by connecting residents to each other and their environments through smart technologies. Achieving this vision will require solving complex and interlocking physical, social, behavioral, economic, and infrastructure challenges, which will only be possible through close engagement with community stakeholders to understand the community needs and develop actionable solutions. This proposal is for the first S&CC Program PI meeting. The meeting will allow Principal Investigators (PIs) from NSF's S&CC Program and graduate students spanning multiple technological and social disciplines to interact with NSF Program Directors, community partners and stakeholders, and representatives from other Federal Agencies in order to disseminate project objectives and accomplishments and foster new and emerging collaborations.

Planned sessions of the PI meeting will address cross-cutting themes of S&CC, including improving outcomes in under-served communities and sustaining S&CC technologies beyond the development and prototyping stages. These discussions will be enhanced through networking activities for NSF PIs and participating community partners. In addition, the S&CC PI meeting will be held in conjunction with the Smart Cities Connect annual meeting, which brings together city and municipality leaders who are working on S&CC problems and are interested in forming partnerships with others including academic researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2018 NSF S&CC PI meeting, held in Kansas City brought together stakeholders including PIs, community partners, industry representatives, students, and federal agencies to discuss, and disseminate the results of the first year of the NSF S&CC program funded projects. 

 

The PIs shared their first-year accomplishments, shared lessons learnt in ensuring collaborations with community partners and transitioning their research outcomes, and exchanged ideas with other participants regarding future opportunities. This exchange of ideas was facilitated by keynote sessions, lightning talks, interactive panels, and networking events.

 

The keynote by Peter Norton (U-Va) presented the pitfalls and unintended consequences of a ?data-driven? approach to urban planning. Drawing on the history of Kansas City, he explained how a myopic focus on improving road traffic metrics led to local and state policies that reduced environmental sustainability and negatively impacted underprivileged communities. This keynote also broadly highlighted the need to be aware of the potential perils of not engaging all the stakeholders in community planning and decision making in any smart and connected communities? efforts.

 

PI meeting also had an excellent panel that provided insight into the importance of having planning grants as part of the NSF S&CC call for proposals in helping teams of universities and community partners develop successful collaborative research proposals. Panels on prototyping and sustaining smart cities discussed methods for maximizing impact beyond the lifetime of the NSF grant. City representatives provided their perspectives on adoption and implementation of smart cities technologies. Further outcomes arose from the two special sessions hosted by the Department of Transportation and Environmental Protection Agency. The DoT special session highlighted research opportunities in smart infrastructure. The EPA session increased awareness of the challenges faced by declining urban and rural communities and explored how smart technologies can help to address those challenges.

 

An additional outcome of the meeting was encouraging networking among computer scientists, engineers, physical and social scientists, municipal policymakers, and agency representatives who typically have limited venues and opportunities for interaction, thus stimulating future collaborations. The PI meeting encouraged participation in the program by junior faculty by including them in the workshop planning and organizing committees.
